titleStmt.title: Distinct Biases Shape Perceptual Inference Dynamics Along The Autism-Psychosis Spectra

analytic.title: Distinct Biases Shape Perceptual Inference Dynamics Along The Autism-Psychosis Spectra

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Predictive processing suggests that variations in precision-weighted perceptual inference can track individuals across the autism-and psychosis spectra. Psychosis is linked to a relative under-weighting of low-level priors, while autism may arise from a tendency to overestimate environmental volatility. This study empirically test computational accounts of the autismand psychosis spectra. In an online experiment (N=150), we recorded participants' orientation judgements of sequential Gabor stimuli alongside their autism-and psychosis-like traits. Perceptual decisionmaking was modelled as a Bayesian time-series, with trial-wise responses resulting from a mixture of current-and prior information on short-and long timescales. Through a series of mechanistic models, we explored how sub-clinical scores modulated the usage of priors from different timescales. In model comparisons, the winning model suggests a reduced weighting of stable stimulus features with increasing autism-like traits. Furthermore, heightened psychosis proneness was associated with a more variable relationship between stimuli and percepts. Our results align with computational accounts of autism and psychosis as disorders of precision with idiosyncratic tuning tendencies. We advocate for an integrated view on perceptual disturbances in mental disorders, considering the continuous expression of autism and psychosis.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Schizophrenia Spectrum Disorders (SSD) and Autism-spectrum disorders (ASD) are prevalent psychiatric disorders, at an estimated point prevalence of 1%, respectively (Brugha et al., 2011;Saha et al., 2005). SSD are a set of debilitating mental disorders characterized by psychosis, with delusions, i.e. extreme beliefs that reside outside cultural norms; and hallucinations, such as hearing voices (Arciniegas, 2015;Fenton et al., 1997). The etiological mechanisms underlying SSD remain opaque, with a number of genetic, perinatal and environmental factors likely interacting non-linearly (Cornblatt et al., 2009;Tandon et al., 2008;Walker et al., 2004). ASD are neurodevelopmental disorders with an onset in early childhood (Sauer et al., 2021). Symptoms of ASD include impairments in social interaction and -reciprocity and restricted, repetitive interests and behaviors.

There is a growing consensus that ASD and SSD are present on a spectrum, beyond categorical or dichotomous diagnoses (Guloksuz and van Os, 2018;Lord et al., 2018). Indeed, sub-clinical levels of autistic traits (AT) and psychosis proneness (PP) are present in the general population, with clinical diagnoses at the extreme ends of the respective spectra (Heinrichs, 2004;Lord et al., 2018;Van Os et al., 2009;Weickert et al., 2013). Sub-clinical levels of psychotic symptoms and schizophrenia are linked to SSD via an etiological continuum ( Barrantes-Vidal et al., 2015;Nelson et al., 2013). For example, high levels of schizotypy are associated with an increased vulnerability for developing psychosis (Camisa et al., 2005). AT, similarly, share a significant overlap with ASD, suggesting an etiological continuity between AT and ASD (Hoekstra et al., 2008;Ronald and Hoekstra, 2011).

In the last decade, predictive processing has emerged as a general framework of brain function in health and disorder (K. Friston, 2010;K. J. Friston et al., 2014;Hohwy, 2013). Its core tenet is that the brain models its surroundings in an iterative, probabilistic process. Since the brain does not have direct access to its external surroundings, it entertains a statistical model of how sensory information is generated (the generative model ). Algorithmically, predictive processing is implemented via hierarchical message passing between the highly interconnected layers of the cerebral cortex (Hohwy, 2020). Sensory information cascades up to higher hierarchical levels bottom-up. Here, it is compared to top-down predictions from the generative model. The ensuing prediction error is leveraged to update the generative model (K. Friston, 2005;Happé, 2005).

An individual has to strike the right balance between "trusting" their model of the world (prior beliefs), vs. the current sensory information (likelihood, Gold and Stocker, 2017;Kersten et al., 2004). To achieve this, the brain estimates the reliability, or precision of sensory information and prior beliefs. Bayes-optimal inference then relies on the integration of precision-weighted prior and likelihood. Chronic imbalances in this process may render an individual prone to mental disorder (K. J. Friston et al., 2014;Huys et al., 2016;Palmer et al., 2017;Pellicano and Burr, 2012;Sterzer et al., 2018).

Imbalances in precision-weighted inference are central to Bayesian accounts of psychosis (Eckert et al., 2022;Stein et al., 2020;Sterzer et al., 2018;Teufel et al., 2015). On lower hierarchical levels, a reduced precision of prior beliefs and/ or increased precision of sensory information leads to a reduced prior-to-likelihood ratio (Sterzer et al., 2018;Weilnhammer et al., 2020). The resulting prediction error may lead to inappropriate model updates. Higher-level priors may be overly precise in an attempt to compensate for the large model updates, resulting in rigid beliefs that cannot be revised in light of conflicting evidence (Adams et al., 2013;Haarsma et al., 2022). Consistent with this, Weilnhammer et al. (2020) found that schizophrenia patients show increased sensitivity to sensory information when viewing a bistable stimulus compared to controls. Individuals with increased sub-clinical levels of PP showed a reduced weighting of prior information derived from trial history (Eckert et al., 2022), similar to individuals with diagnosed SSD and auto-immune psychosis (Stein et al., 2020). Another study showed reduced perceptual-level priors, but not cognitive priors with increasing PP (Stuke et al., 2019). Further, PP has been linked to an improved utilization of higher-level prior information when interpreting ambiguous images (Teufel et al., 2015), and conditioned hallucinations (Powers et al., 2017).

Predictive processing converges with other theories in suggesting a weakened utilization of contextual information in ASD ( Baron-Cohen et al., 2009;Happé, 2005;Koldewyn et al., 2013;Palmer et al., 2017). ASD have been related to a detail-oriented processing style (weak central coherence, Happé, 2005, systemizing vs. empathizing, Baron-Cohen, 2010Baron-Cohen et al., 2009) and, in turn, a bias against extracting global information from a scene (Koldewyn et al., 2013). In Bayesian terms, ASD may result from a chronically reduced weight assigned to prior beliefs (hypopriors, Palmer et al., 2017;Pellicano and Burr, 2012). Imprecise priors in ASD may explain superior performance in artificial perceptual tasks, where prior beliefs hinder performance (Mottron et al., 1999;Pellicano and Burr, 2012). In most naturalistic contexts, however, priors increase the reliability of sensory signals. Overly imprecise priors may increase the expectation of variability, leading to characteristic symptoms such as reduced adaptation after repeated exposure (repetition suppression, Ewbank et al., 2015;Turi et al., 2015). Neural markers support sensory hypersensitivity in ASD, with increased fMRI responses to auditory, visual and tactile stimuli in ASD patients compared to controls (Green et al., 2013). Studies on history biases in ASD have yielded highly heterogeneous results, with studies finding an increased (Feigin et al., 2021), decreased (Lieder et al., 2019) and unaltered (Bosch et al., 2022) serial dependence bias.

Conceptually, ASD and SSD are often cast in terms of opposing perceptual strategies (Hohwy, 2013;Tarasi et al., 2022). Specifically, individuals with ASD show a tendency to assign increased weight to current sensory information. In contrast, overly precise abstract priors may play an important role in SSD, with a decreased precision of priors on more sensory levels. Importantly, theoretical considerations in ASD and SSD converge with respect to information processing on lower hierarchical levels. Previous studies have related both ASD and SSD to an increased sensitivity to sensory information (Weilnhammer et al., 2020;Zaidel et al., 2015) and/ or a decreased influence of prior beliefs on sensory-level processing (Eckert et al., 2022;Pellicano and Burr, 2012;Sterzer et al., 2018). To identify idiosyncratic perceptual strategies along the psychosis-autism spectrum, it may be crucial to consider environmental factors, such as stability or volatility (Palmer et al., 2017;Sapey-Triomphe et al., 2021). In changing environments, individuals with ASD show the tendency to over-estimate environmental volatility (Lawson et al., 2017). In contrast, individuals on the schizophrenia-spectrum show rigidity in their prior beliefs (Eisenacher and Zink, 2017;Tarasi et al., 2022). We here sought to directly investigate perceptual strategies across the autismand psychosis spectra when confronted with high and low levels of environmental variability.

To our knowledge, only one prior experimental study has directly contrasted perceptual disturbances along the autism-and psychosis spectra. In a visual statistical learning task, Karvelis and colleagues (2018) found evidence for a decreased weighting of prior beliefs with higher AT, but not with increased PP (Karvelis et al., 2018). A Bayesian model indicated that this finding was driven by an increased precision of sensory information in ASD (Karvelis et al., 2018), in line with theoretical accounts (Brock, 2012;Palmer et al., 2017;Van Boxtel and Lu, 2013).

In the present study, we recruited individuals from the general population and investigated perceptual decision-making in relation to their self-reported, sub-clinical AT and PP. We developed a Bayesian time series model of choice dynamics and hypothesized that 1. Individuals with high AT will show a reduced adaptation of perceptual priors to longer-term environmental regularities.
2. Individuals with higher PP will discount short-term perceptual history in processing sensory information.

A schematic overview of the hypotheses to be tested in this study can be found in figure 1. Individuals with psychosis or elevated PP (left panel) show an overall reduced precision of sensory-level priors (Eckert et al., 2022;Stein et al., 2020;Sterzer et al., 2018), in combination with an elevated precision of the likelihood (Weilnhammer et al., 2020). We hypothesize that the adaptation to environmental regularities or slow-changing features is unaltered in individuals with high propensity to psychosis compared to individuals with low levels of psychosis proneness (Eckert et al., 2022). In contrast, prior evidence suggests that ASD and AT (right panel) are characterized by an overly precise representation of current sensory information (likelihood). Consequently, the adaptation to stimulus regularities on short timescales is unaltered in individuals with high-vs. low levels of AT (Karvelis et al., 2018;Tarasi et al., 2022). In ASD or heightened AT, we assume a reduced variance induced by environmental variability (Lawson et al., 2017). Psychosis or high PP (left) is associated with an overall reduced precision of priors (purple) and a slightly increased precision of the likelihood term (grey). While prior precision is reduced, there is a slight adaptation to environmental regularities (i.e. stable (upper panel) and variable (lower panel) environmental statistics), and the posterior is shifted slightly towards the imprecise prior in stable environments compared to variable ones. Autism (right) is characterized by an increased precision of the likelihood term, with an intact precision of priors. Of note, there is no, or reduced, adaptation of posterior beliefs to environmental statistics in autism. Typical inference (center) is characterized by a flexible adjustment of prior precision according to environmental contexts.

div.head: Experiment
div.p: The experiment consisted of a sequential orientation reproduction task administered online.

The task was implemented using jsPsych (v.7.3, De Leeuw, 2015), specifically, the jsPsych-Psychophysics plugin (Kuroki, 2021) and administered via JATOS (Lange et al., 2015). Prolific was used for participant recruitment (Palan and Schitter, 2018).
Each trial started with a fixation period of variable duration (200-400ms) on a grey background.

It was followed by a supra-threshold Gabor patch (spatial frequency: 0.03 cycles/ pixel, phase: 50°, size: 800 x 800 pixel, standard deviation of Gaussian: 30, contrast: 0.1), presented on the center of the screen for 550 ms. The Gabor was masked with random white noise. After stimulus presentation, the noise mask was presented for additional 100ms, after which a white line appeared.

Participants were able to adjust the line's orientation using the j (2°clockwise rotation) and f (2°12 counter-clockwise rotation) keys on their keyboard. When the participant was satisfied with their response, they could log it by pressing the space key. Whenever the maximum response time of 8000 ms was exceeded, the experiment moved on to the next trial and the response was recorded as missing (see Figure 2). Additionally, 10% of trials were non-stimulus or non-response trials. In non-stimulus trials, the Gabor was segmented into 16 squares, which were first distorted to remove any orientation and then randomly ordered and rotated. This ensured that the non-stimulus contained no information on orientation, while keeping luminance constant. In non-response trials, a stimulus was presented, but instead of the adjustable, white response bar, a black, non-adjustable line appeared along with the prompt "Press space to continue". Further, there were two types of blocks: stable and variable. In stable blocks, the Gabor orientation was drawn from a standard distribution with a subject-specific, randomized mean M sbj and standard deviation of σ=10°. In variable blocks, the Gabor orientation was drawn from a broader normal distribution with µ = M sbj and σ = 100 (for example stimulus distributions, see supplement 6.2). The block manipulation was implemented to investigate the adaptation of inferential parameters to longer-term statistics.

One block consisted of 25 trials, and there were 8 blocks. Before starting the experiment, all participants read detailed, step-by-step task instructions and completed a demonstration, where they practised all trial types. Participants were then randomized to one of two block sequences: VSSVSVVS, or SVVSVSSV (where S=stable, V=variable blocks). Figure 2. Trial sequence. Stimulus-response trails (A) were presented on 80% of trials. A Gabor patch was presented under a mask of white noise and participants were asked to reproduce the stimulus orientation by adjusting a white response bar. In non-response trials (B, 10% of trials), a stimulus was presented, but a thick black bar appeared on the response screen instead of the usual white response bar. The thick response bar was not adjustable by participants, and accompanied by the prompt "Press space to continue". In non-stimulus trials (C, 10% of trials), a scrambled version of a Gabor patch was presented under the noise mask. D The distribution from which the Gabor orientation was drawn varied block-wise. In stable blocks, the Gabor orientation was drawn from a narrow distribution (µ = M sbj , σ = 10), whereas in variable blocks, the Gabor orientation was drawn from a broad distribution (µ = M sbj , σ = 100).

div.head: Questionnaires
div.p: Participants were prompted to complete two self-report questionnaires after the experimental part of the study: the Cardiff Anomalous Perceptions Scale (CAPS, Bell et al., 2006) and the Autism Quotient (AQ, Ruzich et al., 2015). For the CAPS (self-reported PP), we used the sumscore of all items marked with "yes". Similary, the AQ (self-reported AT) is formed by summing over participant's responses over a 4-point Likert-scale, including some reversed items. Both scores were z-transformed.

div.head: Statistical analyses 2.3.1. Bayesian perceptual dynamics
div.p: We implemented a series of Bayesian models of perceptual dynamics, all of which follow a similar rationale. In all models, the current percept P t is a weighted mixture of short-term stimulus statistics (such as previous percepts, P t−1 , P t−2 and stimuli S t−1 , S t ), and stable stimulus features (here, the subject-specific mean orientation M sbj (stable), and slow-changing block statistics b t ).

The mixing of long-and short-term statistics is governed by parameter φ. The architecture of the graphical model is shown in figure 3. A time series of percepts P t to P t−2 , as reported by the participant, form a Markov chain. On a hierarchically lower level, the trial's corresponding stimuli S t and S t−1 are treated as observed variables and follow a Von Mises distribution. The mixing of M sbj and P t−1 is given by
div.formula: µ t = (1 − φ) * M sbj + φ * P t−1 ,(1)
div.p: with priors
div.formula: P t ∼ vonM ises(µ t , σ P ) (2) P t−1 ∼ vonM ises(µ t−1 , σ P ).(3)
div.p: M sbj is the subject-specific mean orientation that was randomly selected at the beginning of the experiment for each participant; and φ is the mixing weight. φ follows a logistic sigmoid (inverse logit) function given by

σ P governs the variance of the dynamics of the participant's choices over time. Priors over bias ω and β t were set to ω, β t ∼ N (0, 1) 1 . In our model, we assume that this variance adapts with block properties B (i.e., variable vs. stable blocks). σ P is given by
Stimuli are modelled as
div.formula: S t ∼ vonM ises(R t , σ S )(6)
div.p: The variance in the relationship between stimuli and percepts is modelled by σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ)),
with ζ ∼ N (0, 1). A large variance corresponds to a more noisy relationship between stimuli and percepts, whereas a smaller value indicates a close match between stimuli and percepts.

Starting from this basic model architecture, we developed a series of models to systematically investigate the modulation of perceptual dynamics by sub-clinical levels of AT and PP. The models differed in their assumptions about the precise role of the clinical scores in the time series (modulating either φ, σ P , σ S , or none).

div.head: Variations of main model and model comparison
div.p: We implemented a series of 17 models to test the relationship between clinical scores and short-vs. long-term stimulus dynamics. For an overview, see Table 1, and supplement 6.3. All models were implemented in Python 3. Sampling was performed using the pymc3 package (v.3.11.5, Salvatier et al., 2016), and ArViz (v.0.14.0., Kumar et al., 2019). The models' marginal loglikelihood was evaluated using Bridge sampling (Gronau et al., 2017), implemented in a custom library.

We hypothesise that AT modulate the adaptation of perceptual inference to context-and/ or slow-changing stimulus regularities (in line with Lawson et al., 2017). In our experiment, AT may affect the extent to which block statistics influence perception, i.e., we hypothesize a trade-off between block parameter γ and the weighting of AT, represented by α:
div.formula: σ P = log(1 + exp(τ + γ t * B + α t * AT ))(7)
div.p: Figure 3. Basic model architecture A chain of percepts is described by observable variables Pt for the participant's percept. The percept is determined by the stimulus St displayed on the current trial t, the subject-specific mean M sbj and the balancing factor φ. t: trial, P : percept, S: stimulus, µt: subject-specific mean, σ P : variance of transition dynamics, σ S : variance of perceptual error. The basic model architecture is later augmented with additional variable nodes representing the modulating influence of the clinical scores. Filled nodes are observed within the trial, unfilled nodes are unobserved.
Similarly, AT may modulate the influence of stable stimulus regularities, i.e., the subject-specific mean orientation (model):

In contrast, previous findings suggest a reduced influence of short-term prior experience in perceptual inference in SSD (Eckert et al., 2022;Stein et al., 2020). We hence hypothesize that individual PP score modulates the sequential dynamics, with less information carried across trials into the current perceptual decision (e.g. via parameter φ, see Figure 3). This is modelled as an explicit modulation of the mixing parameter φ, φ ∼ logit −1 (ω + β t * P P ).

In a similar vein, PP may affect the precision of sensory inputs (comp. Weilnhammer et al., 2020), suggesting a modulation of σ S σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ + β t * P P )) (10) The basic model architecture shown here is later augmented to match the winning model from the model comparison.
div.formula: Nr AT PP Name 1 σ µ main-model 2 σ σ aq-caps-sigma 3 σ σ S aq-σ-caps-σ S 4 σ none aq-σ 5 µ µ aq-caps-mu 6 µ σ aq-µ-caps-σ 7 µ σ S aq-µ-caps-σ S 8 µ none aq-µ 9 σ S µ aq-σ S -caps-µ Nr AT PP Name 10 σ S σ aq-σ S -caps-σ 11 σ S σ S aq-σ S -caps-σ S 12 σ S none aq-σ S 13

div.head: Non-stimulus and non-response models
div.p: In the experiment, 20% of trials were randomly selected to be non-stimulus or non-response trials (10% each), which were modelled using an adapted version of the main model. To model these trials, we derived the winning model from the model comparison and fit this model to data from non-stimulus-and non-response-trials, respectively, with one adaptation: for non-stimulus trials, the current stimulus is sampled rather than observed. The effects of trial history in absence of a physical stimulus are of interest (cmp. Fischer and Whitney, 2014). In contrast, in nonresponse trials, the current percept is unobserved, probing the effect of trial history on current percept in the absence of a response in a previous trial. For a schematic overview of non-stimulus and non-response trials, see figure 4.

div.head: Results
div.p: N=150 participants performed an orientation-reproduction task online. figure 5A). The average duration of the study was 27.2 minutes (± 9.4 minutes).

div.head: Bayesian Choice Dynamics
div.p: In the raw, quantilised (10% vs. 90% of AQ and CAPS scores, respectively) data, reproduction errors were modulated by clinical scores and block statistics (5B,C), suggesting a decreased modulation of reproduction errors by block statistics in individuals with heightened psychosis proneness scores (5B) and an increased modulation of reproduction errors by block statistics in individuals with high levels of autistic traits (5C) compared to individuals with low levels of autistic traits.

div.head: Model Comparison
div.p: We included 17 models in a model comparison in which the AT and PP scores systematically modulated µ t , σ, σ S , or nothing. All models' marginal log-likelihood was computed using Bridge Sampling. Results are bench-marked on the winning model and shown in figure 6. There are five models that scored significantly better compared to all other models (aq-µ-caps-σ S ;

aq-caps-σ S , caps-σ S , aq-σ S and aq-σ-caps-σ S ). The winning model (aq-µ-caps-σ S , marginal log-likelihood (LLK): -137742.12, all remaining LLK are reported in relation to this benchmark), contains a modulation of φ by AT, φ t ∼ logit −1 (ω + α t * AT ) and a modulation of σ S by PP score, i.e. σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ + β t * P P )) (see supplement 6.1 for detailed description).

According to the winning model, increasing levels of AT heighten the weight of previous percept for the current percept. Increasing PT scores, in contrast, render P t a worse representation of S t . In second rank is a model in which both clinical scores modulate σ S (aq-caps-σ S , ∆LLK = −2.01; σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ + α t * AT + β t * P P ))). In third rank is model caps-σ S with σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ + β t * P P )) (∆LLK = −4.64;), in which any modulation by AT is omitted. Similarly, in fourth rank is model aq-σ S with σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ + α t * AT )) (∆LLK = −4.64;), in which a modulation by CAPS is omitted. Finally, a model in which AT modulates σ P and PP modulates σ S is ranked closely to the winning model with ∆LLK = −5.86 (aq-σ P -caps-σ S with σ P = log(1 + exp(ζ + α t * AT )) and σ S = log(1 + exp(ζ + β t * P P ))).

div.head: Winning model aq-µ-caps-σ S
div.p: In the winning model, AT modulates the mean balancing between short-and longer-term priors (µ t ), while PP modulates the variance of σ S (see table 2). We observe a positive interaction between AT and µ t , α (α AQ aq:priming, mean= 1.213 ± 0.38 SD, HDI = (3%: 0.504, 95%: 1.938)), which can be interpreted as an advantaged weighting of short-term priors (i.e., the previous percept),
3.4 Non-stimulus and non-response trials Figure 6. Results of the model comparison Difference in marginal log-likelihood with respect to the winning model aq-µ-caps-σ S .
compared to stable and unchanging regularities in the environment (i.e., the subject-specific mean orientation

div.head: Non-stimulus and non-response trials
div.p: In 10% of trials, scrambled Gaussian noise was presented instead of a Gabor patch (non-stimulus trials). In order to analyse these trials, we adapted the winning model, aq-µ-caps-σ S , such that the stimulus remains unobserved. Another 10% of trials were non-response trials, with the current response remaining unobserved in the model. Results are summarized in tables 3 and 4.

The modulation of µ by AT remains positive as in the winning model, suggesting a reduced weighting of the subject-specific stable mean orientation also in the absence of a stimulus on the current trial. Similarly, the modulation of the likelihood variance by PP is present in the nonstimulus trials, albeit smaller in magnitude. In the non-response trials, the modulation of µ by AT remains positive. This suggests an increased reliance on perceptual-and stimulus history with increasing levels of AT in non-response and non-stimulus trials.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: With this study, we investigated implicit perceptual inference and its modulation by autism-like traits AT and psychosis proneness PP. In autism, research converges towards an increased weighting of sensory information compared to prior beliefs and reduced contextualization of informationprocessing (Lawson et al., 2017;Palmer et al., 2017;Randeniya et al., 2021;Sapey-Triomphe et al., 2021). In psychosis and schizophrenia, an increased prior-to-likelihood ratio on more abstract hierarchical levels may be an attempt to compensate for a decreased prior-to-likelihood ratio at sensory levels of the perceptual hierarchy (Eckert et al., 2022;Sterzer et al., 2018). Bayesian accounts of the autism-and schizophrenia spectra overlap in their predictions for perceptual disturbances at lower hierarchical levels, suggesting a reduced prior-to-likelihood ratio in both disorders. Hence, it remains an open question under what circumstances a reduced prior-to-likelihood ratio expresses in autistic vs. psychotic symptoms (Tarasi et al., 2022).

The present study set out to disentangle perceptual strategies in AT vs. PP on sensorylevel perceptual inference. We investigated perceptual decision-making in an online psychophysics experiment. Participants were asked to reproduce the orientation of a Gabor patch. Per block, the mean orientation of the Gabor was drawn from narrow (stable blocks) or wide normal distributions (variable blocks). A Bayesian time series was used to infer the parameters governing perceptual inference from participant responses. A series of seventeen models was implemented, in which the clinical scores systematically modulated the mean weighting of stimulus regularities vs. short-term choice history for current percept (µ), the variance of percepts over time (σ P ), or the variance of the likelihood (σ S ). Given previous findings, we assumed that heightened AT leads to decreased weights assigned to stable stimulus features compared to more volatile stimulus statistics, whereas individuals with heightened PP should show a reduced weighting of short-term choice history. In the model comparison, we find that the winning model assumes a modulation of balancing long-and short-term priors by AT, and an effect of PP on the likelihood factor representing the connection between sensory information and percepts.
1. Increased AT show a decreased weight assigned to stable stimulus features during perceptual inference, in line with a lack of adaptation to stimulus statistics.
2. Increased PP are associated with an increased variance in the likelihood factor, in line with a more variable processing of sensory information.

Autistic traits in our model affected the balancing between prior beliefs derived from sta-the other. Here, we observe a discounting of stable stimulus features during perceptual inference compared to recent choice history. This finding is in line with previous studies suggesting a decreased capacity for contextualized information-processing in ASD (Randeniya et al., 2021;Sapey-Triomphe et al., 2021). Studies have reported increased, (Feigin et al., 2021), decreased (Lieder et al., 2019) and unaltered (Bosch et al., 2022) history biases in ASD. There may be several reasons for this inconsistency. First, the three studies use different stimuli and response formats. The stimulus material's abstraction level may be a relevant factor that has been neglected previously (e.g. learned letter associations Lieder et al., 2019, or low-level visual features, Bosch et al., 2020Feigin et al., 2021). Second, the developmental stage of the study sample may play a role in shaping perceptual inference (children and adolescents vs. adults). An over-weighting of sensory information may develop later in life as a compensatory response to chronically imprecise priors, explaining the deviating findings in children and adolescents (Bosch et al., 2022). Third, autism may not necessarily affect the average weighting of short-term perceptual history, but the variance of the balancing process over time, as suggested by the present study and related work (Lawson et al., 2017;Niehaus et al., 2022). Autism has been related to an aberrant processing of environmental volatility (Lawson et al., 2017;Palmer et al., 2017) and deficits in extracting contextual information (Happé, 2005;Koldewyn et al., 2013;Palmer et al., 2017;Randeniya et al., 2021). Canonical Bayesian accounts of ASD (i.e. generally increased likelihoods or hypopriors, Pellicano and Burr, 2012) may be overly simplifying and unjustified in the face of the heterogeneous empirical findings. Instead, our results support the idea of a deficit in the contextualized estimation of precision in ASD (Palmer et al., 2017).

Psychosis proneness led to an increased variance in the likelihood factor, connecting stimuli and percepts. This suggests an increased variability in the way individuals with heightened PP process sensory inputs. While our model comparison does not directly support reduced history biases with heightened PP (Eckert et al., 2022;Stein et al., 2020), it suggests a reduced precision of sensory inputs during perceptual decision-making with heightened PP. This finding is in line with work on conditioned hallucinations (Powers et al., 2017), where individuals with heightened PP show an increased probability of perceiving a sound that is not truly there after a conditioning procedure. Here, perception is driven by an over-reliance on prior beliefs in individuals with increased PP, and probably a decreased precision in representations of sensory input.

We developed a series of alternative models that were compared to the main model. In the model comparison, a total of five models scored significantly superior to all other models included in the analysis. A modulation of the likelihood σ S by sub-clinical AT and PP scores is common to all winning models, suggesting that clinical scores primarily affect the variance of stimulus-response mappings during perceptual inference.
In a small proportion of trials, participants either did not see a stimulus (non-stimulus trials)

or were not prompted to give a response (non-response trials). When fitting the winning model to data from non-stimulus and non-response trials, individuals with increasing levels of AT showed a greater weighting of perceptual-and stimulus history compared to normal stimulus-response trials.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: The data for this study were collected online, which may have affected the results in various ways. Despite careful study design and appropriate compensation, it cannot be ruled out that participants were inattentive for parts of the experiment. We did our best to identify these participants post-hoc, by excluding participants whose average reproduction error was two standard deviations above the sample's mean error. Further, attentional lapses may have occurred more frequently in individuals with high PP, leading to the finding of reduced weighting of short-term priors (Carter et al., 2010;Chen and Faraone, 2000). While our findings are mostly in line with existing literature, it remains an open question whether the effects can be reproduced in different samples and tasks. For example, we rely on self-reported autism-like traits and psychosis proneness in the general population. In ASD, there is growing evidence that individuals with a diagnosis of ASD differ from those with high AT in crucial aspects (Sasson and Bottema-Beutel, 2022). While the continuous nature of the autism spectrum is widely recognized, ASD and AT may still differ in their task behavior quantitatively and qualitatively (Sasson and Bottema-Beutel, 2022). Future research will have to clarify to what extent our findings generalize to individuals with diagnosed ASD. There is less literature supporting a clear qualitative and quantitative distinction between PP and schizophrenia, with more studies supporting the idea of a (linear) continuum (Barrantes-Vidal et al., 2015). However, we recommend caution when generalizing our findings to SSD.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: We investigated implicit perceptual inference along the autism-and schizophrenia spectra using an online visual psychophysics task. A Bayesian time series model revealed a reduced weighting of stable stimulus features with increasing autistic traits, and an increased variance in balancing sensory inputs and prior beliefs in individuals with higher psychosis proneness. Future studies should investigate the neural basis of this effect and whether it generalizes to clinical populations.

div.head: Specifications of winning model
div.p: Model equations for the winning model (see also supplementary code). Stimuli and reported percepts are modelled via von Mises (or circular normal) distributions, which are determined by a mean µ and concentration parameter σ S .
div.formula: S t ∼ vonMises (P t , σ S )(11)
div.p: σ S , denotes the variance of the stimulus-percept relationship. In the winning model, it is modulated by PP:
div.formula: σ S = log (1 + exp(ζ) + β t • P P )(12)
div.p: the prior on ζ follows a normal distribution
Percepts P t are treated as observed variables with the prior given by
div.formula: P t ∼ vonMises (µ Pt , σ P )(14)
div.p: where σ P follows a softplus function
div.formula: σ P = log (1 + exp (τ + γ t • B))(15)
div.p: The trade-off in balancing prior beliefs derived from trial history vs. the unchanging, subjectspecific mean orientation is governed by parameter φ, which in the winning model is defined as
ω can be interpreted as an individual bias towards short-term priors. φ then determines the balancing of priors derived from the overall distribution mean M sbj
div.formula: µ Pt = (1 − φ t ) • M sbj + φ t • P t−1(17)
div.p: The prior on all bias parameters was set to be
see supplement 6.4 for model comparison results when choosing a prior of α t , γ t , τ ∼ N (0, 3).

The modulation of φ by autistic traits supports the notion of an aberrant balancing of prior beliefs derived from different timescales in sequential decisions, with short-term prior beliefs given by the previous choices P t−1 , P t−2 and longer-term, contextual priors derived from the current block's stimulus distribution (narrow or wide, leading to variable or stable blocks) or the stable, subjectspecific overall mean of these distributions, M sbj . In contrast, psychosis proneness modulates the weighting of current sensory inputs (σ S ).
6.2 Empirical stimulus distributions

div.head: Empirical stimulus distributions
div.p: We visualized the empirical distribution of Gabor orientations for 25 example participants. Orientations are plotted separately for variable-and stable blocks to show the underlying differences in stimulus distribution (7).

div.head: Figure 7. Gabor angles across subjects and block type
div.p: Gabor orientation for 25 example subjects, plotted separately for variable blocks (orange) and stable blocks (blue). The subject-specific, randomized mean is represented by the red vertical line. In variable blocks, Gabor orientations are centered around the subject-specific mean. They were drawn from a normal distribution with SD=10°. In contrast, Gabor orientation values were sampled from a broad distribution with SD=100°.

div.head: All graphical models used in the model comparison
div.p: A graphical overview of all models implemented for the model comparison can be found in figures 8 to 12. All models were summarized using ArViz (tables 5 through 20).

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Graphical model of non-stimulus (left) and non-response trials (right).

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Descriptive plots of clinical scores and choice behaviorA distribution of raw CAPS and AQ scores in the sample. Both scores are uncorrelated, r = 0.07, p = 0.44. B Density of raw reproduction errors, plotted separately for high (↑, blue) and low (↓, black) psychosis proneness scores (PT), and stable (dashed lines) vs. variable blocks (solid line). C Density of raw reproduction errors, plotted separately for high (↑, red) and low (↓, black) scores in autistic traits (AT); and stable (dashed line) vs. variable blocks (solid line). Note: B, C show quantilised data (top and bottom 10%)

figure.head: Figure 8 .
figure.figDesc: Main model (1) and related models with autism-like traits AT modulating σ P

figure.head: Table 1 .
figure.figDesc: Overview of models included in model comparison

One dataset was lost due to a technical error. Five participants were excluded because they reported being inattentive, unable to see any patterns or distracted in the debriefing questionnaire. Another 17 participants were excluded because their average reproduction error was larger than 3 SD above the mean reproduction error. The final sample consisted of N=128 participants (64 female, age 29.28 ± 9.83 (SD) years, mean number of Prolific approvals: 224.5). The average reproduction error was 5°visual angle (±40.02°), indicating a good average task performance. Mean CAPS score was 10.46 (± 6.97), and mean AQ score was 10.56 (±4.35). AQ and CAPS did not show a significant correlation (r=0.07, p=0.44, see

figure.head: Table 2 .
figure.figDesc: ). Further, a positive weight resulted for the interaction between PP and the variance of the likelihood, σ S (β caps , caps:σ S , mean= 0.312 ± 0.013, HDI 3%= 0.025, 97%=0.264). σ S represents the variance in the relationship between stimuli and percepts. Increased σ S with higher PP scores suggest a more variable processing of stimuli in perceptual inference for individuals with higher PP. For summaries of all other models, see supplementary materials 6.3. Winning model summary

body.note: To probe the choice of prior variance, we implemented all models with a wide prior variance (supplement 6.4)

div.p: Acknowledgements. We would like to thank the members of TAM for helpful discussions at an early stage of this project, especially Dr. Sanna Stroth and Dr. Inge Kamp-Becker.

div.head: Choice of prior variance
div.p: To examine the effects of the choice of priors for parameters α t , β t , γ t , τ, ω, and ζ, all 17 models were fitted with a wider prior variance, i.e. for example α t ∼ N (0, 4). As becomes evident from supplementary figure 13, the choice of prior has a negligible effect on the results of the model comparison. The winning model continues to be model 7 (aq_mu_caps_sigmalik).
